t: Judges 5
The Song of Deborah
On*p that day Deborah and Barak son of Abinoam sang this song:
“When*pn the princes in Israel take the lead, when*ld the people willingly offer themselves— praise*ld the Lord!*s
“Hear*pn this, you kings! Listen, you rulers! I,*ld even I, will sing to the Lord;*s I*ld will praise the Lord,*s the God of Israel, in song.
“When*pn you, Lord,*s went out from Seir, when*ld you marched from the land of Edom, the*ln earth shook, the heavens poured, the*ld clouds poured down water.
The*ln mountains quaked before the Lord,*s the One of Sinai, before*ld the Lord,*s the God of Israel.
“In*pn the days of Shamgar son of Anath, in*ld the days of Jael, the highways were abandoned; travelers*ld took to winding paths.
Villagers*ln in Israel would not fight; they*ld held back until I, Deborah, arose, until*ld I arose, a mother in Israel.
God*ln chose new leaders when*ld war came to the city gates, but*ln not a shield or spear was seen among*ld forty thousand in Israel.
My*ln heart is with Israel’s princes, with*ld the willing volunteers among the people. Praise*ld the Lord!*s
“You*pn who ride on white donkeys, sitting*ld on your saddle blankets, and*ld you who walk along the road, consider*ln

the voice of the singers at the watering places. They*ld recite the victories of the Lord,*s the*ld victories of his villagers in Israel. “Then*pn the people of the Lord*s went*ld down to the city gates.
‘Wake*ln up, wake up, Deborah! Wake*ld up, wake up, break out in song! Arise,*ln Barak! Take*ld captive your captives, son of Abinoam.’
“The*pn remnant of the nobles came down; the*ld people of the Lord*s came down to me against the mighty.
Some*ln came from Ephraim, whose roots were in Amalek; Benjamin*ld was with the people who followed you. From*ln Makir captains came down, from*ld Zebulun those who bear a commander’s staff.
The*ln princes of Issachar were with Deborah; yes,*ld Issachar was with Barak, sent*ld under his command into the valley. In*ln the districts of Reuben there*ld was much searching of heart.
Why*ln did you stay among the sheep pens to*ld hear the whistling for the flocks? In*ln the districts of Reuben there*ld was much searching of heart.
Gilead*ln stayed beyond the Jordan. And*ld Dan, why did he linger by the ships? Asher*ln remained on the coast and*ld stayed in his coves.
The*ln people of Zebulun risked their very lives; so*ld did Naphtali on the terraced fields.
“Kings*pn came, they fought, the*ld kings of Canaan fought. At*ln Taanach, by the waters of Megiddo, they*ld took no plunder of silver.
From*ln the heavens the stars fought, from*ld their courses they fought against Sisera.
The*ln river Kishon swept them away, the*ld age-old river, the river Kishon. March*ld on, my soul; be strong!
Then*ln thundered the horses’ hooves— galloping,*ld galloping go his mighty steeds.
‘Curse*ln Meroz,’ said the angel of the Lord.*s ‘Curse*ld its people bitterly, because*ln they did not come to help the Lord,*s to*ld help the Lord*s against the mighty.’
“Most*pn blessed of women be Jael, the*ld wife of Heber the Kenite, most*ld blessed of tent-dwelling women.
He*ln asked for water, and she gave him milk; in*ld a bowl fit for nobles she brought him curdled milk.
Her*ln hand reached for the tent peg, her*ld right hand for the workman’s hammer. She*ln struck Sisera, she crushed his head, she*ld shattered and pierced his temple.
At*ln her feet he sank, he*ld fell; there he lay. At*ln her feet he sank, he fell; where*ld he sank, there he fell—dead.
“Through*pn the window peered Sisera’s mother; behind*ld the lattice she cried out, ‘Why*ln is his chariot so long in coming? Why*ld is the clatter of his chariots delayed?’
The*ln wisest of her ladies answer her; indeed,*ld she keeps saying to herself,

‘Are*ln they not finding and dividing the spoils: a*ld woman or two for each man, colorful*ln garments as plunder for Sisera, colorful*ld garments embroidered, highly*ln embroidered garments for my neck— all*ld this as plunder?’
“So*pn may all your enemies perish, Lord!*s But*ld may all who love you be like the sun when*ld it rises in its strength.” Then*p the land had peace forty years.
